section.paragraph: Denial of Service attacks are mostly directed at gaming websites and servers, although companies’ websites are often targeted as well.

An American company Universal Tube and Rollform Equipment used the URL utube.com, but people looking for YouTube typed this URL by accident, causing unintentional DOS attacks on the company’s website. The company took legal action and now use utubeonline.com to avoid more similar attacks.

DerpTrolling are a recent hacker group that mainly use Twitter to announce their DDOS attacks, seemingly for “internet fame”. They claim to have been operating since 2011 but rose to prominence when they targeted the popular online game League of Legends and publicised live using a Skype call to a popular streamer. They then proceeded to take down the gaming servers of Dota2 and Club Penguin when “PhantomL0rd” switched to playing to them.
Bitly, a site which offers shortened URLs, was taken down by a DDOS attack in February 2014. Users reported that they couldn’t click on links to URLs shortened by the site.

Anonymous are a "Hacktivist" group that was started on the messageboard 4chan in 2003. Many people know them for their Guy Fawkes masks, which members wear when protesting in public. Their actions to date include participating in 2011's Occupy Wall Street protest, and

They also launched a DDOS attack on the Westboro Baptist Church's website and eventually took it down after the Church announced plans to picket the funerals of the victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School; in addition to this, Anonymous published names and contact information for many members of the Church.

LulzSec (short for Lulz Security) is a small branch of Anonymous that are responsible for several very high profile attacks, including taking the CIA's website down via a large DDOS attack, and leaking details of Sony customers' usernames and passwords in retaliation for Sony attempting to stop users from hacking PlayStation consoles.
